ilo: Have an appreciation of the factors that need to be managed if enterprise-wide software is to be implemented on time, within budget, and produce on-going benefits for its host organisation

Demonstrate the likely direction and impact of technological innovations such as in-memory databases, mobile computing, business intelligence and artificial intelligence on future enterprise system architectures

Develop a good understanding of the capabilities of enterprise-wide ICT-based application software, e.g., enterprise resource planning (ERP), customer relationship management (CRM), supply chain management (SCM)
Gain hands-on experience in using SAP ERP system, the most popular enterprise application software packages to support business processes
generic_skills: Argument analysis, i.e. the ability to identify arguments and evaluate the evidence that authors provide to support their arguments. Argument analysis is one of the most important skills a person can develop
Ability to collaborate with different individuals through group work and discussion

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief:
One group assignment (3 members): analysis of Enterprise Systems related case studies. Intended Learning Outcomes (ILO's) 1, 2 and 3 are addressed in the group assignment. 



Students must obtain a minimum weighted average mark of 50% for the two assignments.

One individual assignment: understanding SAP ERP software. 



It involves completing two modules and writing a reflection of approximately 1500 words. The first module is due in week 6, the second module in week 8 and the report with reflection in week 12.



ILO's 1 and 4 are addressed in the individual assignment.



Students must obtain a minimum weighted average mark of 50% for the two assignments.
One written 2-hour closed book end of semester examination. ILO's 1 to 3 are addressed in the examination.
assessment.hurdle: Yes, To pass the subject, students must obtain at least 50% of the marks available in the examination.

date_times.contact_hours: 3 hours per week, comprising of one 1.5-hour lecture and one 1.5-hour workshop in computer labs.
